Based on the light novels by Ichiei Ishibumi, HighSchool DxD is a 12 episode anime series produced by TNK and released in 2012. The story focuses on Issei Hyoudou, a recently human turned devil and servant to one of the most popular girls in his school, Rias Gremory. It then turns into Issei dealing with the three factions of Christianity and to accomplish his never ending quest: to become the "Harem King!"
Story: 7
As stated, the series is about Issei Hyoudou, an average perverted second year high school student at the former all girl school Kuoh Academy. Then one day, Issei meets a mysterious girl namedYuuma Amano, who confesses to Issei and becomes his first girlfriend. At this point, Issei is riding high. This does not last long, as after their first date together, Yuuma attacks Issei and then leaves him to die. Then, the next day, Issei believes that his death was just a dream and goes onto school as if nothing is wrong. However, Issei soon finds out that nobody remembers who Yuuma is or that she was his girlfriend (her number was even erased from his phone). It is then that later that night, Issei begins to experience strange things happening to himslef. He can see in the dark as if it were day, he can hear people from very far away, and he can jump much farther. Things begin to take a turn for the worse as our young hero is soon attacked by a strange man who has the same black wings that Yuuma possessed and the same method of attack as well. It is at that moment, that Issei is saved by one of the "Two Great Onne-Samas" of Kuoh Academy and his senior, Rias Gremory. However, all he sees is his rescue and nothing more before he passes out. Th next day, Issei wakes up to what he thinks is just another dream. However, he soon finds himself in a state of undress (in the nude) and right beside him Rias Gremory in a similar state as him. This surprises Issei and causes him to freak out a bit, causing the girl to wake and act extremely calm, even though she is naked in front of a boy. She then reveals that she is a devil and that Issei is now her new devil servant. End of episode one. 


And my reaction: ...I'm sorry, what? Honestly that came as a surprise. The whole thing with Yuuma was rather unexpected and while the main character dying and be resurrected is nothing new in an anime, most of those characters knew they were killed, while Issei was kept in the dark about it, only to be told that he is now a devil and servant by a naked girl who is not shying away. Not a bad way to be told you got killed in my opinion.


So from there, we go into story that focuses about how Issei is dealing with his new resurrected state, his dealings with the three factions of Christianity (devils, angels, and fallen angels), and his quest to rise up the ranks and become a high-class devil so that he may achieve his dream of becoming the "Harem King!". Now my overall opinion on the story is that I do actually like it. The plot of an average kid thrown into a world of the supernatural is not new in the slightest, but HighSchool DxD does it in a way to give it a charm. It also has much more dramatic moments than most would give it credit for. It can switch from a comedic story into a dramatic story and does it very nicely as well. The story is also a lot deeper and more complex than I think most would like to admit as well.


Art/Animation:7

The studio that produced and released this series is TNK, better known for the anime adaptation to Ikki Tousen, Kannazuki no Miko, and *shudders* School Days. TNK is really that well known for having great animation or artistic achievements. However, this has to be one of their better looking titles in those terms. The animation for HighSchool DxD is very pleasing to the eye and has rather well done motion, especially in the jiggling of breasts, fight scenes that were energetic, intense, and well done. The art is also very beautiful in my opinion, as there is a mixture of colors that make the show pop out. The character models here have been done with great care. The female cast here are made to look sexy, beautiful, cute, and stick out, and boy do they ever. Each girl is looks differently and each are memorable in their own ways. And while the animation is rather nice and pleasing, it's not top-tier stuff. I also have to mention that the ending is one of the most well animated and eye pleasing endings I have seen.


Music:8

One of the reasons I liked this show was because of its soundtrack. I have Ryosuke Nakanishi to thank for that as he made this soundtrack rather memorable. While Ryosuke could have gone a more traditional route and had more harem, ecchi, comedy music to go to this series, he chose a different route. He instead gives the soundtrack a rather more dramatic, movie like, and orchestral feeling to it. And what makes it work and memoralbe is that each piece gives atmosphere to the scene that it is being played with. Two examples I like to bring up are Rias Gremory's theme, a slow and beautiful piece that gives off a rather melancholic feeling to it, and Beautiful Red, an intense and fast paced piece played during critical moments of the show and gives off a rather orchestral feeling when it is played. Overall, the music for HighSchool DxD is very well done and memorable at that.


Characters:7

Another aspect that I liked about this series was its characters. The characters are rather interesting to watch as each one is rather distinctive. And although this is a harem show, right now only two girls are really in love with Issei. Also, they don't fight over Issei as much as other harem anime do. They love him, and get jealous when he is with another girl, but they are not obsessed with him and fight over him at any given moment, but they also just live their lives normally. I really don't see that done a lot in this genre of anime.


First let us talk about our main character. As stated, Issei Hyoudou is your average perverted high school student who is resurrected into a devil after he is killed. While he first starts off as a perverted, breast loving teenager...he still is that, but he also develops as the series goes on. You see that besides being perverted, he is kind, compassionate, brave, and a hard working guy. He also provides a lot of comedy for the show as being the butt monkey a lot. He is also willing to go to the extreme to protect his friends and loved ones. Like with Rias, he sacrificed his arm to help save her from a terrible fate and he charged through several exorcists to save Asia. But what I liked about him is that he is much different from a lot of harem main protagonists. The reason is that he actually admits he is perverted and he is not ashamed of this fact. Most other harem MC will follow a similar pattern: they are nice guys which attracts the girls, get nervous when they see a girl naked or anything like that, faints or passes out because of that. Issei does not do that: he will faint once or twice if sees a girl naked, but that is due to him getting a nose bleed. He also admits that he wants a harem, unlike a lot of other MCs. And despite his perversity (which I don't mind), he is rather well done character and a nice guy. He also created one of the greatest anime powers ever: "Dress Break".


Second on our list is the lovely female lead, Rias Gremory. Rias is the heiress to the noble house of Gremory, one of the remaining devil houses in the underworld. While one might expect here to be rather arrogant and stuck up because of her noble background, that isn't the case for her at all. Rias is a kind, compassionate, and caring individual. She loves her servants like they were own family and will not allow anyone to harm them (god save whoever has). And while she fell in love with Issei, it was more of a progressing love. Her feelings towards him were a little brother type of love in the beginning. It soon began to develop as time went on and when Issei told her that he liked her for who she was: not Rias Gremory the heiress, but Rias Gremory his master. Her love continued to grow as he kept fighting for to free her of an arranged marriage which she had no desire to go through with and never gave up even as his body was broken and beaten and finally reached its climax when Issei literally charged in during her engagement party and declared that her virginity was his and then fights her fiancee to free her from the marriage. Rias is the type of female lead that I can really like for her actions, personality, and looks.


The third big character to talk about is Asia Argento.Asia was originally a nun from the church who was revered for her healing abilities, but was one day cast out and excommunicated when she healed a devil without knowing. When she moves to Japan, she comes across Issei who helps her out. Then, during another encounter, she finds out that Issei is a devil but she tries to dismiss that fact as she knows that Issei is a good person at heart and her first real friend. After a series of events, Asia is resurrected and is brought into Rias's peerage. Asia in general is a sweet, innocent, caring young girl. She is very naive, which is taken advantaged of by her new school friend that she make. Asia is a also very devoted to Issei and loves him deeply, and will become sad if anything were to happen to him. In fact she is so devoted that she helped him when he was creating his "Dress Break" move by using it on her (to which she happily agreed to do so). 


With the villains of this show, they're there. The come in, do what they do, and leave. That's not to say they are bad villains, just that they make the arc go along and will be defeated as the arc ends. But I did enjoy them such as Freed, the psycho priest banished from the church because he loved cutting up devils and humans too much; Raynare, Issei's first girlfriend and a rather cold hearted bitch; and Raiser, one of the children from the house of Phoenix who is Rias's fiancee and a rather arrogant ass to boot as well. Like I said, the villains aren't bad, they're there to help the story progress farther. And in all honestly, I like that.

Okay, I’ll get serious now. The plot of High School DxD is not all that compelling. It’s pretty generic stuff. I pretty much saw this as the opposite version of Sora no Otoshimono, where the characters are devils instead of angels, and the tits are much more prevalent. I didn’t mind this though as the plot did move at a decent clip and I guess it wasn’t the worst I’ve seen.


It’s more character driven than anything, though none of the characters are standouts. Issei is the same tired character we’ve come to find in a lot of this type of anime, the strong-headed pervert who’s useless in every regard except he’s got a lot of heart. Rias is somewhat interesting as the leader of the little group. All the other girls are pretty much generic characters we’ve seen a million times before.


By now this is a pretty tired tale but there are some redeeming factors to this anime that actually exceeded my expectations.


Boobies.


I was actually recommended this anime by a girl at my local anime convention so I figured it just be another Heaven’s Lost Property. But it’s entertaining as hell.

Sure, every third shot was a boob or a thigh or panties, but the comedy helped make this unabashedly shameless. There are some anime that are just boobies and panties  for their own sake and then some comedy thrown in. But High School DxD is so shamelessly filthy and perverted that it’s actually somewhat charming.

What do you get when you combine the religious mythology of Paradise Lost with the fanservice of ecchi anime?
High School DxD.
Wait -- da fuq? How can a masterpiece like Paradise Lost (praise John Milton) be spoken in the same breath as Issei’s Fan Club and Friends? What the hell (pun intended) are you implying? Can an ecchi anime that features nude pics of its main characters midway through each episode even be good?
Well. As flagrant as its shots of boobs, panties, butts, and what have you may be, for an ecchi it is surprisingly good. In fact, if the purpose of ecchi is precisely toappeal to the target audience that would even watch this kind of stuff, then DxD is superb, for the ecchi direction caters exactly to that. We get generous, copious, amounts of NSFW images with that soft, lustrous tint you see surrounding girls’ nipples and defining girls’ lips. Issei blushes profusely and often, the lucky bastard, and even wakes up to several naked girls all vying for his attention. What’s more, the very impetus behind Issei’s powerups that in most shounen would be nakama power is, yes indeed, lust. Not to discount the nakama power that does exist, very strong actually, but the fear of seeing Rias’s boobs halved in size being enough to spur him on? Brilliant.


Moreover, DxD has plot, and by plot I don’t mean “plot” but actual plot, the series of events providing a vehicle for character change, world exploration, etc. I’m reading Paradise Lost for my Milton class this semester and I’m legitimately getting the same vibes with DxD -- that indescribable feeling of awe in the face of untouchable, higher beings. The conflict of DxD over its three seasons concerns three primary groups, namely the divisions of God’s angels after the war in Heaven into the devils, fallen angels, and loyal angels. In the present day, much much after that war, these big names still exist and when they interact with the human (-ish) main characters… it’s crazy. Not to mention the notable voice actors chosen for certain roles which only accentuates the coolness. I mean like there’s this one scene where the leaders of each group are sitting at a table, so much power gathered in one place. Hell yeah.


The aforementioned nakama power arises vis-à-vis the Occult Research Club. Rias treats her chess pieces as family, and as the story progresses we get solid development and backstory for each one. The tantalizingly unconsummated romance between Issei and Rias always hangs in the background (poor Rias) with Issei continuing to call her President akin to Godai’s calling Kyoko Manager in Maison Ikkoku. As the Club tackles each battle, the members grow closer, and by the third season (BorN) it is genuinely precious to behold. As for Issei’s harem (who to choose?), well, his dream of becoming the Harem King is essentially realized. But more than being an all lovey-dovey harem, DxD highlights the strong bonds between Issei and his fellow club members; their anguish at seeing a nakama in danger and pain is very akin to the anguish we see in the Straw Hats for another of their crew.


In terms of music, if you like sweeping orchestrals and frolicking simple tunes, then you’re bound to enjoy the OST of DxD. Its sonorous qualities match the grand scale of the events, the seriously celestial force of individuals clashing, the power to emanate from an outstretched hand. If only the fights were better animated, but then again we can’t expect anything comparable to ufotable’s work in Unlimited Blade Works.


The OPs and EDs? The OPs present their corresponding arc events/characters as necessary, and the EDs are as mediocre as can be for an ecchi (as many nude shots as possible). I didn’t really care for the ED music but the OPs I really liked, definitely more serious than what I’d expect from an ecchi (frilly high-pitched female vocals).


I enjoyed this best on Crunchyroll (good animation). When I tried it on other sites (much worse animation) it was hard to watch. The only thing worse than plenteous oppai is badly visualized plenteous oppai. The fights were, as I noted, just OK, but seeing Issei boost and change his mecha-dragonesque appearance multiple times was pretty slick (plus having the voice of Madao/Hasegawa from Gintama pumping up the MC was quite interesting). Being a fan of fantasy and mythos, seeing the plethora of big names like Azazel and Michael was awesome, and seeing Rias fully bare in the flesh -- and caressing Issei -- and faintly coloring at the thought of Issei -- and caring for her subordinates so dearly -- and her oppai -- and her tenderly rounded derrière -- and her vivid scarlet hair -- and I digress. In terms of the bod, Rias Gremory is my #1 girl, matched only by perhaps Senjougahara Hitagi from the Monogatari universe. Issei you lucky, fortunate man.


Could DxD have not been an ecchi? Hmm. Not really. It would change the story drastically because the ecchi and plot are so intricately intertwined. DxD is good ecchi, and I say “good” in the sense that the fanservice and sensuous elements are made endemic to the plot and MC’s growth rather than being mere add-ons. Take Highschool of the Dead for example, remove the ecchi and you could have 90+% of the story intact; that’s superfluous ecchi. Heck, any show can be made ecchi simply by having the girls dress more scantily and have plenty of clothes being ripped apart, etc. And to taint the arduous fervor of DxD by removing ecchi from its name would be a blasphemy. By the gods and demons and dragons above and below, I need more oppai, more Rias, and hopefully a suitably tender moment between her and Issei to round out the show. I look forward to High School DxD Hero.

So recently I've been told my reviews are biased and unfair, so I'm going to try to write this with the least bias and unfairness I have. Highschool DxD is a special show. It's a show constantly praised for it's ability to, how the fans call it, "mixing 'plot' and 'plot.'" Which is basically saying that this show didn't do what every other ecchi show did with shoehorning plot into ecchi, but instead shoehorned ecchi into plot. It's not like this doesn't work, in fact it works very well. The plot is strange at first, but the viewer will quickly get used to it. Myproblem is with the ecchi. It just feels like what I said just before. It's justt shoehorned in ecchi. This show will throw around ecchi like no tomorrow. In one scene, you'll see Rias undressing for the shower, then you'll see someone undressing to seduce Issei, then it's back to Rias coming out of the shower naked. But then there's an intense battle, but the clothing is from Senran Kagura, and it tears off like tissue paper. (I actually really like Senran Kagura for obvious reasons) So the battle is no longer a tense battle with real dangers, but I just see a battle with some tits flying around. Riveting. Some people might argue that if the ecchi is good, then it shouldn't matter. Right? Well, the ecchi is pretty meh. It's not that it's bad, and I'm sure it got better as the show gained more popularity and pumped out higher quality seasons, but that's not the season I'm here to review. The ecchi is average. It doesn't wow me with it's immense detail, it just is ecchi. I'm not saying it's terrible, it just got stale with every scene featuring at least one tit. This part is going to be biased, so you can skip to the next marked part if you don't want to read it. --- It also doesn't help when the girls all look like toothpicks with balloon tits. It doesn't look too appealing at all. This show does something most ecchi shows don't, and it should be applauded. It was able to write a good plot with the ecchi. The plot works. It functions. It does the unthinkable. It makes the plot good in an ecchi tagged show. I actually enjoyed the plot, I thought it was interesting. Even better, it matched good characters with this plot. They didn't go very far with them, and I can't blame them it's first season, but they were good nonetheless. Then the plot is matched with some decently good music, and I can't help but enjoy even if slightly. That's the end of my praise with this show, thought. Although, it had these good things, it wasn't my cup of tea. I have an even better metaphor for it. It's a cake with shitty icing on it, and the cake flavor isn't my favorite. Like, carrot cake with lemon icing. I'm sure some people taste it was chocolate cake with strawberries on top, but I just don't like it. I don't hate this show, I simply don't like it. But even if I don't like it, I'm not the god of anime by a long shot. If you like ecchi, watch this show immediately. And if you have already, make sure to watch the other seasons. This show has plenty of promise, and I'm sure fans of this type of show would eat this up like a delicious cake. I'll end this with a solid 5, low 6. It's good, but I'm positive it'll get only better from here.

Review on English Dub: The High School DxD Franchise is a combination of comedy, harem, ecchi, and romance. DxD is by far one of the highest-rated harem television shows out there, and here is why. Compared to other harem/ecchi shows, High School DxD knows how to deliver a solid plot line as well as execute it. For an ecchi, DxD shows better character development than other popular shows. 
Starting on the protagonist, (by far my favorite) Issei Hyoudou has a lot he brings to the table. If you are a fan of crude humor and sexual jokes, you are going to love this. The mainquality that makes him an enjoyable character is his pervertedness. Issei has NO mental filter that keeps him from saying embarrassing things. This is a large part of the comedy in High School DxD. Scott Freeman does an excellent job portraying Issei Hyoudou. DxD got the nomination for the best male and female voice performance, with Scott Freeman playing Issei and Jamie Marchi as Rias Grimory. The show received the BTVA Anime Dub Television/OVA Voice Acting Award in 2015. Along with being a complete pervert, Issei is also reliable. This is his heroic trait that allows him to save the day and appeal to the ladies (despite his unpopularity). 


The story continues to keep the flow with new and exciting elements as well as hilarious comedy. The process of the protagonist going from a loser to a hero is comedic as well as exciting. Came for the “plot” stayed for the plot.
Each year tons of harem and ecchi anime come out, but the problem is that most of them, while perfectly enjoyable, aren't particularly great, so finding quality ones is quite the effort. I have heard of a few bright spots in the sea of mediocrity, and the one that was pointed out as something better was High School DxD. So when I was really swamped with collage work, and needed something to unwind to, I decided to give it a try, but never did I expect it to be as great as it turned out to be.
In thebeginning we are introduced to Issei, who is your average perverted high school boy, on his quest to get ahold of some scrumptious breasts. He one day gets asked out on a date by this gorgeous girl, but when the date ends, she turns into a monster (well actually a fallen angel as we later find out) and kills our poor Issei. Thankfully the horny teenager he is he thinks of a super hot girl, Rias Gremory, he had seen at school, who happens to be a demon, and accidentally summons her to save himself. She saves him, but in exchange for his life he gets turned into a demon and becomes a part of her demon group, that operates in his school under the Occult Research Club.


The thing about the story is that, while it won't win any awards for originality, it is just executed so well. At no time did I have a bad feeling watching it, as I sometimes have when watching similar anime, as it was never offensively stupid. The point is that while there is a lot of nudity in the show, it is surely not the only thing it has going for it, as the story progresses in such a way that it constantly makes you want to know what is going to happen next, and doesn't just make you crave for more nudity. It manages to be serious at times but overall it just exudes positive energy and makes for a great anime to unwind to, while still offering something a bit more substantial. Quite surprisingly the anime manages to keep a steady pace, and there were no especially weak episodes. The ending was well done and fulfilling, while still being a nice starting point for a second season.


One of the stronger points of this anime are its characters. Our main character Issei is at first presented just like your average sex-obsessed teenager, but he reveals another side of him, one that is extremely caring and loyal. I have to say I can understand why the girls come to like him, even though the first impressions he makes are generally negative. One thing I can't understand about him is the way he responds to this affection girls show him, as he is always thinking how to get nearer some of the girls, but when he actually gets the chance, he does nothing.

Our female lead is Rias Gremory who is Issei’s master. She comes from a very distinguished demon dynasty and was always looking for someone who would like her for what she was, and not for her family connections. She finds that person in Issei, as he is completely new to the world of demons and is completely loyal to her, because she saved his life. We can see she cares a lot about the rest of the group and constantly tries to make them as satisfied as possible. 

Later on we are introduced to another important character in form of Asia, an exiled nun with the power of healing both humans and demons. She is in some serious trouble but Issei helps her get through, and so she joins the group. She shows extreme gratitude towards Issei as he saved her and is also in love with him. I found this relationship between them a bit strange, as Issei sees her as someone he needs to protect, but he is not romantically interested in her (yes, he fantasises about having her, is there a female in the show he fantasise about), while she is completely in love with him. She is also timid enough to do nothing serious about his relationship with Rias, but rather suffers quietly and thinks of herself as a martyr.

We also have a whole slew of secondary characters, and they are mostly great if a bit unexplored, but hey what can you do in twelve episodes. There are two character I particularly disliked, and they were his two friends, as they are there only to complain about their lack of action. The problem is characters like these are common in the genre, and I have to wonder why. Maybe they are there only to emphasise how lucky the main character is, but I see no reason for the need to emphasise that. The other possibility I could think of is to mock a part of the audience, as they are the kind of people that would watch a show like this, and if that is so, it is funny in a way, but it would be just offensive to the people watching the show as, I still want to believe not many people like those two exist. Well enough of my ranting, as these two are practically the only two characters that I disliked, even though the villains could have been done a bit better, but they still get the job done.


The animation is done exceptionally, everything is smooth, the backgrounds are detailed, and the colours really pop. One thing I have to touch about the animation is the fan-service that really is plentiful. This thing has to have the most nudity I have seen in an anime, but unlike some other anime I have watched, everything is still in good taste (I’m looking at you Yosuga no Sora), but you should still skip this if you dislike fan-service. The sound was nothing special but the opening was still pretty awesome and while the ending was nowhere near as good it wasn't offensive in any way. The voice acting was great, but I still cannot comprehend why are they choosing such character names that the voice actors are unable to pronounce correctly. 


I knew High School DxD was supposed to be good, but I could have never believed, that it was going to as good as it was. The point is that in my opinion fan-service in itself is perfectly fine, but if that is all an anime has going for it, it is going to be a pain to watch. As I had said in the intro you might start watching this for the “plot”, but the story is the thing that is going to get you hooked. All in all it deserves to get a score of 9 out of 10, as while it was great, there are still many places where improvement is possible, who knows maybe if some of them are alleviated in the next season it might even get a perfect score. I do recommend this to everyone who can stand a bit of fan-service, it could even be a good starting anime for some.

What? An extremely ecchi-based series that actually has a decent plot line? Unheard of...
High School DxD (I guess Demon x Demon?) is like a cross between the fights of Ikkitousen and the setting in Kore wa Zombie Desuka. An extremely perverted, girlfriend-less dude named Issei suddenly gets a girlfriend and then promptly dies soon afterwards. He is then reborn as a Demon and serves under high-class demon Rias Gremory.
The first line in the series after the initial intro are along the lines of "ah.. I wanna squeeze some boobs." You pretty much know exactly what you're getting into at that point. However, despite the veryhigh level of ecchi (and surprisingly few god rays), this series actually manages to tell a relatively interesting story; though of course you have to be able to tolerate the amount of ecchi.


This is an above average series for the ecchi-based school-based genre that has decent action and your typical ecchi comedy. Do not watch if you cannot tolerate topless nudity.


Animation:

DxD is pretty good looking overall. The series overall has a slightly unsaturated look despite using some pretty strong reds and blue/purples. The series is not as crisp as it could be in some of the action sequences but I didn't notice it too much as the shiny bright attacks/effects obviously distract from the minor details.


Character styling is nice as well. You have a good mix of distinguishable primary characters, as well as a lot of plain yet differentiated background characters. I'm somewhat surprised at the level of non-censorship that AT-X gets away, I sure don't remember a high school club where all the girls occasionally go topless...


If you haven't gotten the message yet, this is an extremely perverse series, to a similar degree (though in a different way) as Sora no Otoshimono. There are multiple, highly suggestive scenes. This is not quite balanced out by occasional action, most of which involves Issei getting almost killed (again) before being saved by the other demons. As in Kore wa Zombie Desuka, the main male character has unusual regenerative abilities and the series takes advantage of this to bloody things up.


Assuming you can deal with the blood/boobs, this series is fairly good looking.


Sound:

The OP is reminiscent of other girl-based fighting shows and the ED somehow reminds me of Infinite Stratos, both aren't anything remarkable but suitable for the series. The BGM is appropriate, I liked the stringed instrument parts, but is overall forgettable.


The VA cast is composed of surprisingly many veterans. Almost all the main and relevant supporting cast have very strong voice actors. Asia's VA is comparatively new but does a really good job in bringing out her personality.


Story:

So Issei apparently possesses a "Sacred Gear", some sort of magical weapon that is inside him (think Makens from Maken Ki). These Sacred Gear are important in the three-way war/battle between angels, fallen angels, and demons; and Issei is killed to prevent him from being a threat to any of the groups. Luckily for Issei, he is picked up by a high-class demon named Rias and suddenly is given a second chance at getting his Harem. Unfortunately he starts out as a weak, low-class demon and must train to become stronger.


The story can be divided into two main arcs that both have a good mix of rising action/climax/falling action. The first deals with Issei's induction as a demon and a fight with fallen angels. The second arc deals with Rias and her fiance demon. In general, both arcs are both interesting despite a fairly predictable progression.


This isn't a perfect work. Certain episodes felt like filler material, and the everyone-gets-sacrificed grand finale is way overused. There are also lots of elements that aren't totally explained (or are over-explained given their relative unimportance) but the series does set it self up for a season two and perhaps elements will be clearer then.


Character:

If you take a look at the cast tab, you'll quickly deduce that this is a character-spamming series. There are at least two dozen characters that appear, take on a really minor role, and then quickly disappear never to be seen again. In general, I frown upon such a practice, but in this case the series successfully develops the main characters despite the extra baggage.


Issei is your typical hopelessly-ecchi guys who also happens to be nice and has an indomitable willpower (not too different from Zombie Desuka). He happens to then join a family of demons that apparently takes on the "Occult Club" role in the school. You have a good mix of character personalities ranging from cute moe/shy to ultra-sadistic.


Character relations are surprisingly well done considering the ecchi focus of the series. Many of the characters here are dynamic and change noticeably due to interactions with each other. Issei's relationships are probably best summed up as "it's complicated."


Value:

The value of this series will greatly depend on your tolerance for ecchi. The story and character elements are fairly good for this genre and I found the overall progression enjoyable.

Usually whenever I watch a Harem it's mostly the same thing, but there are few that I consider gems because they don't just focus on the fanservice and this is definitely one of them.
The story begins with Issei Hyoudou a regular teenage pervert desperately looking for a girlfriend then suddenly his wish is answered, but it was a trap as the girl he liked was actually a fallen angel and attempted to kill him, however Issei was saved by the Devil known as Ria's Gremory and from this point Issei's life would forever change for the better.
Now surprisingly for a Harem anime itactually has a pretty interesting story as it concentrates on the world of Devils and Angels along with the addition of a third party called Fallen Angels, getting to know each of their societies and history was actually very interesting to learn, during this season it mainly focuses on the Devils and the different houses they have along with the different roles that the members have whose powers are very similar to the pieces on a chess board.

The first season focuses on two arcs the first is about Issei and Asia's introduction to the Occult Research Club and pretty much what the rules are and the jobs they have to do since they are servants of Ria's, but it also focuses on the Fallen Angels who attacked Issei and wish to use the powers Asia has since they are very rare.

The second half focuses more on Ria's and her forced marriage to Riser Phoenix, the battle between the two houses shows how well Issei and the others worked together as there is some strategy involved in the fights that do happen in the series, it also shows how determined Issei is to protect Ria's and the other's in the club.


Now the characters were great out of all the harem anime's I've seen this definitely has the best mix of characters.

Issei is the male MC and is a really perverted guy, but despite his perverseness he actually does care for his other teammates and is willing to die to protect them no matter what the situation is, he also gains the powers of the Scared Gear known as Boosted Gear which actually has the Red Dragon Emperor known as Ddraig who helps Issei learn the powers of the Boosted Gear.

Ria's Gremory is the female MC and the leader of the Occult Research Club, even though she has an amazing figure she definitely shouldn't be underestimated because Ria's is certainly a badass and will use her powers to protect her servants, she is actually a very kind person and always wants to make sure her servants are safe from harm, she is also a good leader too as she always plans out a strategy whenever her team enters a battle with another Devil House.

Asia Argento is actually a nun of the catholic church that Issei befriends until she is captured by the Fallen Angels who wanted her rare ability called Twilight Healing that is until Issei and the others came to help her and after that she joined Ria's House as one of her servants. Asia is a shy, innocent and is fairly inexperienced at socialising which makes such an adorable character and her interactions with Issei and the other club member really helps prove this.

Akeno Himejima is Ria's Queen and is pretty much the most powerful member alongside Ria's, she is a very flamboyant character always teasing Issei (and us the audience) with her figure, but that doesn't mean she can be serious because if you get in her way you probably won't survive.

Koneko Toujou is the loli and Tsundere of the group she is also Ria's Rook and despite being small she has incredible strength as she is able to throw objects easily and has a powerful punch which she uses on Issei a couple of times because of his pervy nature.

Yuuto Kiba the other male character of the group is Ria's Knight and is considered the best looking guy in Kuou Academy by the ladies which makes Issei jealous of him until he knows he is working for Ria's, since they are the only male characters they get on very well and Kiba has a strong heart towards the protection of his friends.

Now High School DxD isn't known for having strong villains, but they get the job done. Raynare is the main villain for the first half of the series and is a Fallen Angel, despite her revealing outfit she is actually pretty powerful that is until Issei kicks her ass, Riser is the main villain for the second half of the series and is a very cruel person not caring much for his servants other than sexual desires and his overconfidence of his powers eventually led to his downfall, then finally there is the guy known as Freed Sellzen who is an Exiled Exorcist he's that type of villain you hate and like at the same time because his overzealous personality really made for some funny yet aggravating moments.


Now the artstyle was pretty good as the powers each member of Gremory team has were pretty damn cool especially Issei's Boosted Gear which does change from a metallic glove to a full bodied suit which was epic to look at, the uniforms were actually pretty slick and the characters looked well designed too especially the female characters, the intro and outro were actually surprisingly catchy and just didn't seem like something you would skip.


Now the fanservice is what we all came for and it is pretty consistent, but it doesn't take me out of the show like other Ecchi anime's, all the female characters had well made figures yes even Asia and Koneko and it really did make for some funny comedic moments which included the greatest power of all time which is the dress break power that Issei eventually learns which means he could break girls clothes just by touching them and this is certainly a power all men want.


The action compared to other Harem anime's wasn't just mindless punching and throwing yourselves at the enemy there was actually some strategy to it like when Ria's house was up against Riser's house, before they started fighting Ria's made sure to send her best people to the right areas and this felt really satisfying that they were coming up with plans and not just blindly running into the fire.


Overall this is a fantastic show, if you're into Ecchi/Harems then you need to check this one out and it won't disappoint you because trust me I've had quite a taste of Harem anime's and none have surpassed this one.

Note: This will be a review of the series in its entirety.
Overview:
Honestly, out of all the many anime genres out there, the ecchi/harem genre is easily the most controversial. Oftentimes, the writers will focus solely on pleasing the audience's perverted desires, while neglecting anything even resembling a decent story. With that in mind, it's easy to see why "High School DxD" is commonly seen as one of the prime examples to do the genre right. Make no mistake, "High School DxD" is as ecchi as they come, but it doesn't use its fanservice as a crutch to hold up sagging plot and characters.
Story & World(8/10):

The story follows Issei Hyoudou, a perverted 17-year-old student at Kuoh Academy, a former all-girls school that has recently turned co-ed. Obsessed with breasts and dreaming of having a harem, Issei is unexpectedly asked out on a date, and even more unexpectedly killed at the end of it, with the girl revealing herself to be a Fallen Angel. However, Issei is in luck, as he gets rescued by a Devil named Rias Gremory, who later declares herself to be his master. Yeah, turns out Fallen Angels and Devils are two separate beings in this universe, and Issei has been turned into one of the latter to save his life. He then becomes a member of the Occult Research Club, which is a front for Rias's base of operations. Basically, Issei has to do jobs for humans, compete with other Devils in fighting matches and help Rias and her other servants defend themselves from both Fallen Angels and Angels. And Rias states if he does a good job, he may just have some servants of his own one day. Upon hearing this, Issei resolves to fulfill his dream of having his own harem, and to become the "Harem King".


What makes the story great is that the status of things is constantly changing. In the hands of most other writers, Issei would constantly try to woo women to no avail, fail in any attempt at progression towards his goal and after three or four seasons of searching for his killer, he'd be no closer to finding her than when he started. "High School DxD", however, is nothing like that. Enemies are dealt with as soon as possible, with only a select few being given a second chance. The girls falling for Issei is also a gradual process, with it generally not happening until he does something to really earn their love. And while Issei starts off as something of a butt-monkey, by the end of the fourth season, you get the impression things are really starting to go right for him, making it hard to believe he was ever unlucky.


However, while the story is certainly fantastic by harem anime standards, it's also not without its problems. What the series sorely lacks in is consistency. We start off with Devils, Angels and Fallen Angels, but it isn't long before we're introduced to characters from every mythology you can think of, which can get pretty overwhelming, to say the least. There are times when I honestly forgot just what the story is about. The problem with consistency is also evident in Sacred Gears, ancient artifacts wielded by several characters including Issei. We see that reading a Bible and simply praying to God causes serious pain to Devils, so shouldn't Sacred Gears, which were bestowed upon them by God, hurt them as well? And later on, we have a Devil wielding a holy sword, which were established earlier to be able to annihilate Devils and that simply touching them is highly toxic for them. This contradiction is never even brought up in the series, so we're basically supposed to accept it at face value without any real explanation given. As far as plot holes go, this is pretty damn inexcusable, though maybe I'm reading too much into it. 


Art & Animation (8/10):

The animation is pretty good, but not what I'd call fantastic. For the most part, it looks great but there are several moments where rough edges become noticeable. Also worth noting is that the fourth season is done by a different studio from the other three, meaning the art style is given a complete overhaul, which may disappoint some people. There are also times when the fanservice can be too much, such as when a character's breast is clearly visible in what's supposed to be a very sad moment, though thankfully this doesn't happen often.


Sound & Dialogue (8.5/10):

The soundtrack is all over the place- in some scenes it's great, but there are other scenes when it can be very ill-fitting. I actually noticed a couple of times when the exact same track was played for two scenes with completely different tones. There's a different opening for each season, but none of them stood in my mind quite as much as the first, which is used brilliantly in the respective season's final showdown. The voice acting is solid, and I would definitely recommend watching the dub, as it really ups the funny, perverted dialogue, which really fits the silly tone of the series, and Jamie Marchi in particular does a fantastic job as Rias. It should be noted, however, that several voice actors are replaced over the latter two seasons, most notably Issei's and Akeno's, which may take a bit of getting used to.


Characters (7.5/10):

We'll start with the man himself, Issei. He initially comes off as a lecherous asshole, and is seen as such by nearly his entire school. While he is lecherous, by the end of the first episode, it becomes clear he's not an asshole at all. He's not even a jerk with a heart of gold. He's actually a really nice guy who will go out of his way to ensure a girl enjoys a date as much as possible. There's a reason all the main girls end up falling for him, and that's because he's a protective badass who often goes to hell and back (both literally and metaphorically) for them. He's also very respectful of their feelings, and refuses to take advantage of them in a depressed state, even if they're the ones making the move. This chivalrous nature becomes especially apparent when we see other characters who already have what he has, but are complete assholes because of it and treat the women like their property. That said, while Issei's perverted antics are certainly funny, there are times when they can be just plain ridiculous. During one fight, he goes through all sorts of crazy power-ups in an attempt to keep up with his opponent, but the thing that finally gives him the upper hand is fear of his harem's chests getting smaller (it makes sense in context). There's also the fact that he's ALWAYS the one to fight the main villain of an arc, even when it would make more sense for another character to fight them, making him something of a spotlight-stealer in his own series. Nevertheless, as far as harem protagonists go, Issei ranks among one of the very best, and has very much earned the affection of the girls around him.


However, my favourite character would have to be the aforementioned Rias. The other characters are technically her servants, but that's very easy to forget since she really doesn't treat them like her servants at all. She gets them to do errands and commands them in battle, but more often than not she acts more like a surrogate mother or older sister figure. Her affectionate nature towards the others, Issei in particular, is really sweet and had no problem winning me over as early as the first few episodes. She also has an extraordinary lack of shame, and has no problem being naked in front of others (when she wants to be at least), to the point that her reaction to someone walking in on her is simply a polite "Good morning!" without even trying to cover herself up. For people who dislike the tsundere always being the lead, Rias is most certainly a breath of fresh air. She can be a tad selfish and possessive when it comes to Issei, despite his desire to have a harem, but it should be noted that Devils are explicitly stated to be selfish beings by nature, and not even really kind ones like Rias are immune, so I had no problem looking past this. Besides, despite her usual mature nature, she is still a teenage girl, so I'd say this kind of behaviour would be normal even if she wasn't a Devil.


Next up, we have Akeno, the vice-president of the club and Rias' best friend and first servant. She comes off as a refined lady most of the time, but in combat she becomes a giggling sadist, often smiling as she electrocutes enemies. She's also a big pervert and just as shameless as Rias, though also much more forward and loves teasing Issei. The series also features a prominent male other than Issei, namely Yuuto Kiba, the Prince of the school and a total badass with a sword, who eventually becomes Issei's best friend (essentially, he is to Issei as Akeno is to Rias). There's also Koneko, a small girl with massive strength and a very sharp tongue, who makes me laugh practically every time she opens her mouth, and Asia, a former nun who joins the club shortly after Issei and has a Sacred Gear that allows her to heal anyone, be they humans, Angels or Devils. She doesn't fight, but she is pretty much the one keeping the group together, and it's often shown just where they would be without her.


However, there are quite a few characters I didn't like. In season three, we're introduced to Rossweisse, a Valkyrie, who doesn't have much personality to speak of. She's cheap, more conservative than the other girls and very pessimistic, all of which serve to make her pretty annoying. Also, in season 3, Loki as a villain. Gee, never seen that before. Additionally, Loki is usually portrayed as a complex anti-villain with sympathetic motives, but this version is just a generic doomsday villain who wants to destroy all of reality because.... reasons. This is, without a doubt, the worst version of Loki I've seen. Hell, the "Son of the Mask" character is more fleshed-out than this version. The problem is that the extra mythologies often don't feel necessary since they don't add all that much to the story. The devil and angel characters are who really matter, and thankfully, they're usually great.


Enjoyment (8.5/10):

"High School DxD" is a hugely enjoyable series. The action scenes are plentiful and awesome and there were more than a few moments where I just could not stop laughing, in no small part thanks to Koneko. Sure, sometimes the jokes can get a bit repetitive, but that doesn't happen very often, and the constant shift in status keeps the series from ever getting boring. 


Overall:

"High School DxD" is a fantastic twist on the harem genre. It won't win prizes for consistency and doesn't do anything particularly original, and some may be off-put by the perversions or just find the whole thing pretty juvenile. However, if by chance you're looking for an ecchi/harem anime that combines a healthy amount of fanservice with an actually good story, then this is exactly the one you should watch.


Score:

8+8+8.5+7.5+8.5=40.5/50=8.1/10

Starting off with the artwork of the show it is phenomenal,character and, location designs are smooth as ice. The action sequences of the show are fantastic particularly in the final three episodes and, this is what the show desperately needed more of. Most of the comedy was pretty hilarious and, musical score was pretty decent. 


The opening and, ending songs of the show were completely forgettable, I honestly do not remember a single lyric or frame from either of them. 


The first arc of the show is as generic of a set up as you can get, new guy joins this group and, eventually brings in a new member who is kidnapped and, goes against the orders of the master to save them with the help of other members. The set up while mediocre and, generic has some shining moments. These include Issei discovering his powers, the rescue of Asia from the fallen angels and, some hilarious moments of comic relief. They introduce an absolute arrogant prick of an asshole who is like the perfect douchebag character and, you just want to see him get his ass kicked.

The servants of house Gremory are interesting but, lack development of any kind which sucks because they seem to have interesting backstories. Rias who at first seems like strong independent badass that you would follow into was eventually succumbs to damsel in distress syndrome.

High School DxD looked like your typical harem/action/drama anime like those of previous seasons such as Ladies vs Butlers, R-15, Kampfer and Maken-Ki. Even though HSDXD follows the same agenda, it's significantly better than the harem animes I mentioned.
Story.
So what's better? Well for one the story line is a lot more coherent and serious. Yes there are some silly moments, but the story line does progress mostly every episode and it does it rather quickly which is kind of a downer since it seemed like there was more to it than it seemed. Though it's not their fault. Harem animes like this one (where theygo full nude) tend to get less opportunities for 13+ episodes and the only one that does come to mind that has gone more than that is Seikon No Quasar which I thought was ok. If you were to compare the story line progression with another anime like R-15 or Maken-Ki, I'd say this anime trumps them both significantly. Still since it's sort of rushed, it does have a few plot holes (though not on the level of Guilty Crown which is full of them). So I give it a 7. 


Art

Art is decent. The action scenes are pretty good. The girls are attractive and it does show blood which is surprising since some harem animes tend to leave that kind of stuff out. I give it a solid 7.


Sound

Not particularly great. It's your typical jpop stuff, though some of the background music is pretty such as when they show the "president" they play a violin melody, adds a nice taste. I give it a 6.


Characters

The characters are actually a lot more interesting except that not all of them get an in depth look. The only ones that do are Asia, Issei and Rias, who are pretty much the main leads. Still this a harem anime so character development isn't much of a big deal, but it was a nice addition to the boobs and a** they show on a regular basis. Still the characters are likeable which is a good thing. Though Issei is a pervert, he's not a bad guy as he proved when he saved Asia and Rias. I give them a 7.


Overall

I enjoyed this anime. It wasn't stupid like R-15. It didn't suffer from crappy characters and story like Maken-Ki. It was actually pretty decent which is kind of rare in a harem anime of this type. Yes there are a few plot holes and the end is pretty open ended which leaves hope for consecutive seasons. Overall I give this anime a 7, which is pretty good in my opinion since many harem animes don't usually get this much attention in character and story development. Still if you don't like boobs or nudity or perverted stuff, I wouldn't recommend it. You probably won't like it, but if you don't mind that stuff, you should definitely watch this. It's a lot better than some of the other harem stuff that has come out the previous seasons.

The opening scene of High School DxD gave me the impression it was going to be another generic no nonsense ecchi school anime. Twelve episodes later however, I find myself a little baffled at how much I enjoyed it.
Story: 7/10
While this show’s premise is not very ambitious, it isn’t horrible either. The show starts out with our pal Issei dying from a spear wound from a demon b!tch in a park all alone. His last words call out to our “loaded” red headed president Rias who allows Issei to continue on living by becoming a demon. The plot in generalactually had a very nice pace; there wasn’t any section of the anime where I thought it was dragging. We have the beginning events, the laid back period where most of the stuff happens at school, then the main conflict which arises and ends all within twelve episodes. Most shows that follow in the ecchi format are nothing more than eleven filler episodes with the studio scrambling at the end to make some sh!tty ending. High School DxD genuinely was an interesting show to watch. It didn’t go over the top with its premise but it was far from boring. Some might argue the ecchi content might have gotten in the way but generally since our protagonist is a perv anyway, it didn’t distract me…too much.


Animation: 7/10


So I was lucky enough to get to see this on a BD copy of the movie (courtesy of a friend). The visuals are quite well done; every character model was constantly presented very well, the backgrounds had attention to detail, and fight scenes had great feudality. AND YES for all of you who are just going to watch this for the ecchi stuff do not fret, all the scenes that point out the most awkward camera angles are here for you to enjoy. The BD copy does not hold back at all; where the broadcasted version was heavily censored (at least I was told it was), it's no holds bar here. But like I have stated in my other reviews, I am part of that weird percent of anime viewers that do not watch for the “scenes”; if a show has an interesting plot and very well written characters, I can sit through it.


Sound: 7.2/10


I am very picky about sound since I spend most of my time around music. While the musical score for this anime isn’t genericly bad, it is somewhat average. The music that plays during the fight scenes and around the school sound like any other anime’s soundtrack; there just wasn’t a whole lot of originality here. The voice actors however did a pretty good job; everything was recorded fairly well.


Characters: 7/10


Again while the characters were not “OMG AMAZING”, they also were not a hindrance to the anime. The club’s characters all have an overlying personality that may be somewhat generic but we are exposed to them enough through character development that I started to like all of them by the end of the show. Even though Issei is a pervert crybaby, he genuinely grows throughout the show and becomes pretty badass by the final fight.


Overall: 7.1/10


I was so sure that after the first episode I was going to have another Champione! experience (in other words, a generic boring ecchi anime). But this show really surprised me; even though there was a lot of ecchi content, it worked itself fairly well into the show and since the animation was very good backed with a decent cast, it was overall a good watch. It exceeded my expectations so why not yours?


Enjoyment: 7/10

High School DxD es y por ahora seguirá siendo mi serie favorita, no es la mejor, no es la más interesante, no tiene el mejor desarrollo de personajes y no es tan profunda. Pero a mi me encanta, la habré comenzado a ver cuando tenia cerca de 12 o 13 años, en ese entonces, era un chico con la cabeza llena de testosterona y si llegaba a mirar un simple pezón, ya la tenia mas dura que una pared. Fue, en ese entonces, que me introduje a “High School DxD”, no me acuerdo muy bien cuando ni como comencé a mirarla, pero creo que fuepor un PV o un AMV, donde mostraba imágenes sobre la novela ligera, me intereso mucho el arte con el que estaba dibujado las caras y cuerpos del protagonista y sus compañeras; aunque estos correspondían a la novela ligera, decidí ver el anime.


Creo yo que, en ese entonces, nunca me pude haber dado cuenta que estaba entrando a un mundo completamente nuevo, donde disfrutaría de horas y horas, leyendo, mirando y sonriendo desde el fondo del corazón. 


La Primera Temporada de HSDxD es, sin duda alguna, la puerta hacia la casa en la cual te vas a hospedar, es el comienzo, es subirte a un tren y no saber en que estación bajar, o por lo menos, eso fue para mí. Seguramente muchas personas no lo ven así y lo ven como un anime mediocre y poco interesante, uno que te saca de la acción o que simplemente es puro fanservice, pero para mi fue más que eso.


En los primeros capítulos vemos como nos presentan a Hyoudou Issei, nuestro protagonista, quien vive su vida siendo un pervertido y espiando a las hermosa chicas de su escuela, esta era su vida normal hasta que desafortunadamente es asesinado por quien era su novia. A partir de este momento, comenzamos a recibir mucha información, sobre el mundo, sobre el mismo Issei y también sobre quien es su nuevo amo. Ya que Issei reencarna en un demonio.


Issei comienza a relacionarse en su nuevo entorno y comienza a tomar cariño de sus compañeros y comienza a experimentar nuevas experiencias, valga la redundancia y vemos un crecimiento enorme de quien era en el capitulo 1, y quien se convirtió en el capitulo 12. 


Como dije antes ya sea por la testosterona en mi cabeza o porque realmente me atraía la historia, me termine metiendo en el mundo de HSDxD, me converti en un fanboy.

Sé de primera mano que no a muchos les va a gustar como lo hace a mí y que el primer vistazo que tienen con High School DxD es brusco por todo su ecchi y fanservice.


Mi review sobre su primera temporada es que:


- O es el primer paso para amar la serie.


- O es un paso atrás para no volver a verla de nuevo.



Mi consejo antes de ver High School DxD es que no esperes nada, anda con la mente en blanco y déjate atraer por su música, su mundo y en especial, sus personajes.

I personally prefer to watch this show censored because a) its easier to explain to people, and b) the tits sort of draw from the story. 
Now, as far as that story goes, it is definitely one of my favorites. It feels to me as if it is a perverted representation of Milton's Paradise Lost which is one of the greatestclassics ever written and one that I believe deserves the name "classic". The anime and light novels each also draw upon a great number of other myths and mythologies, which for me was a reason that I fell in love with this show. I greatly love the depictions of mythological characters in this anime and how they fit into the show. The only regretable thing that I don't really like about Highschool DxD is its incredibly powerful anti-religious message. Though I am not a die-hard Christian, this factor makes it impossible for me to recommend this anime to any of my religious friends. It is easy for me to get past and I did not let it factor into my review since I presume most people truly won't care.


The characters are incredibly funny and the show, on the surface, is really lighthearted. However, as you dive deeper, you find this deeply rooted psychological experience manifesting itself within each of the characters within the show. Each character has a tragic past that makes them broken and each of those experiences is what drives their relationships with the other characters. Each character feels unique to me and I love each and every one of them. Even the bad guys are all pretty cool even though they are douches that you quickly learn to hate


As far as the soundtrack goes, I really like this soundtrack. The opening is one of my favorites and the ending makes me laugh every time I see it. I do like the OSTs as well, though against anime such as Attack on Titan, Campione!, and Guilty Crown, it doesn't stand out that much. As such, it lost one point for me there.


In light of all that, I'd still say that it is a great anime despite what others have to say and it will always be one of my favorites. I love the art and I love the characters. The story is deep if you actually look for and pay attention to it. Personally, I feel aggravated whenever anyone says that this show is just tits because its just not the case. It is one of the best Harem genre anime that has earned its high spot on my list.

For a show where they take no shame in their fanservice, it's actually a pretty fun ride from beginning to end. :) (Much like others have said, if you don't like ecchi shows, this REALLY isn't the show for you, considering there is a lot of uncensored nudity. There is also a bit of gore thrown in as well, though it's only really in the beginning and ending halves of the show.)
(+) The characters are fun, with the most favorable points going to our perverted protagonist Issei, who is probably written much better than others like him. The music is addicting (ESPECIALLY that ending), theart is fairly good, and the story, while cliche in some aspects, had a lot of cool action scenes and is just fun all around. 


(-) The only real negative I can find here is that the earlier fanservice is pretty bad (especially in episodes 4 and 5, where it's a little...um...misplaced in a certain section). I will also say that beyond the main cast and the recurring cast, the other characters aren't written well, in that there are only two modes they can be on: over the top villain or regular annoying high schoolers.   


Overall, I just really enjoyed this show for what it was and had a good time with it. If you can handle boobs and blood, then you should really give this show a try, since it's much more fun than some other entries that have come out in the genre lately.


P.S. That ending is seriously awesome and I don't care what anyone else says about it. XD
